topic.title: Extending Qodana
topic.p: Although %product% provides various profiles for inspecting your code, it may be useful to analyze your codebase using third-party inspections that are not covered by standard %product% profiles. This can done in several ways, such as:

li.a: Using custom plugins developed from scratch
Creating inspections based on structural search

chapter.title: Plugins from JetBrains Marketplace
chapter.p: JetBrains Marketplace provides plugins for inspecting code in the IDE. These plugins can be used to extend the %product% inspection functionality.

This section explains how to inspect PHP code using the Php Inspections (EA Extended) plugin and the linter. All actions taken in the IDE are explained for PhpStorm. You can reproduce these steps for any plugin from JetBrains Marketplace you would like to extend %product% with.

procedure.step: Install the plugin and enable it as explained on the Install plugins section of the PhpStorm documentation portal.
Configure the Php Inspections (EA Extended) plugin inspections. For more details, see the Inspections page.
Export the profile containing the enabled plugin inspections as described in the Configure profiles section.

(Optionally) You may need additional plugin configuration options that are usually configured in the Settings window of your IDE. In case of the Php Inspections (EA Extended) plugin, this may be required for specifying Yoda style rules. These options are contained in the options subdirectory of the configuration directory of your IDE.

chapter.title: Custom plugins
chapter.p: Development of plugins is discussed in the section of the IntelliJ Platform Plugin SDK documentation portal.
The plugin should export inspection results to the SARIF format so that it can be parsed by %product% and displayed in a report.

chapter.title: Structural search
chapter.p: Structural search lets you inspect your code based on a particular code pattern or grammatical construct.
As an example, consider the following search template:

This template lets you detect the System.out.println() Java statement with hardcoded text like System.out.println("Hardcoded text!"). This table describes the values of each variable that the search template can accept:

tr.td: Any text enclosed in quote characters.

chapter.p: This procedure explains how use this search template for inspecting your codebase using %product%.

step.p: Using the Structural Search dialog of IntelliJ IDEA, you can create the template as shown below:
Convert the template to inspection as described in the Work with structural search and replace section of the IntelliJ IDEA documentation portal. For example, it can be saved as Hardcoded-print.
In the Settings dialog, enable the inspection in the Structural search group of inspections. For more details, see the Configure profiles section.
In the Inspections section of the Settings dialog, export the updated profile as described in the Configure profiles section.

You can observe the problems detected by the structural search inspection under the Structural search category in the %product% report.
